title: 110_s1646
content: The Act may be cited as the "Wildfire Presuppression Fuels Management Pilot Program Act of 2007". Congress finds that private grazing land in the United States has seen significant increases in cheatgrass and other invasive weeds after wildfires. The Secretary of Agriculture should provide cost-share payments to landowners for fuels management plans to protect grazing land and wildlife habitat from wildfires. Private grazing land in the United States has seen increases in cheatgrass and invasive weeds after wildfires. The Secretary of Agriculture should provide cost-share payments to landowners for fuels management plans to protect grazing land and wildlife habitat. Additionally, there are regulations in place to prevent private land from encroaching on public land and right-of-way. SEC. 3. FIRE PRESUPPRESSION CONSERVATION PROGRAM. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include a provision for producers who develop a fuels management conservation plan approved by the Natural Resources Conservation Service for fire presuppression on private grazing land. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include a provision for producers to receive cost-share and annual incentive payments for wildfire presuppression on private grazing land. The Secretary will provide payments to producers who enter into contracts for activities outlined in the program for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. The contracts will have a minimum term of 5 years. The Secretary may provide cost-share and incentive payments to producers for innovative fuels management conservation plans on private grazing land to prevent wildfires fueled by invasive weed species. Activities include managed fuel breaks with grazing practices and technology implementation. The contracts will have a term of 5-10 years. The Secretary may provide cost-share and incentive payments for innovative fuels management conservation plans on private grazing land. This includes activities like managed fuel breaks with grazing practices, technology implementation, restoration of fire-damaged areas using native plants, protection of critical wildlife habitat, and conservation practices to reduce high fuel loads from woody plant species. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to implement projects for pollution reduction, conservation practices like storing carbon in soil, and innovative grazing management activities.
